_prev_prog_3.Description: The prevention program covers the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system at Arden International LLC.  The process safety management program developed for 1910.119 has been expanded to encompass the environmental issues specific to the risk management program.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ARDEN International, LLC
dba BELLISIO Foods, Incorporated


RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM PLAN
Executive Summary


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at Arden International, LLC Lakeville, Minnesota facility are engrained in the fundamentals of the process safety prevention program.

At the Lakeville, Minnesota facility anhydrous ammonia is used for refrigeration.  The refrigeration system has an inventory of ammonia that is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The same properties that make this chemical valuable as a refrigerant also make it necessary to observe specific safety precautions.  These safety precautions are exercised in the operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system to control human environmental exposure in an effort to reduce the overall threat to workers as well as the surrounding communities and the environment.

It is Arden's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws, rules, and regulations.  However, the safe handling of ammonia is paramount at Arden.  Standards and recommended practices governing the safe handling of ammonia are used to ensure that a reasonable level of risk reduction is maintained.  Investigation of inherently safer technologies, and failsafe design applications are a few of the continuous improvements being studied.  Safety depends upon management commitment, the manner in which ammonia refrigerant is handled, the safety devices inherent to the refrigeration system design, operating procedures and philosophies, and the training of Arden workers.

Arden believes that accountability for safety reaches throughout all levels of management.  Senior management's commitment and dedication to continued safe-operating practices is clearly evident in Arden?s organization structure and employee empowerment.  

Extensive improvements have been made to safety and health programs like the

prevention program (process safety and risk management), emergency preparedness and response, and training.

Additionally, Arden believes employee involvement is the cornerstone to continued safe operations.  This is known as employee ownership and its success is portrayed through lower injury rates, fewer incidents, and improved efficiencies at the plant.

The Emergency Evacuation Plan outlines procedures for warned and unwarned emergencies that may occur at the plant.  Warned emergencies are usually tornadoes, heavy snowstorms, or conditions that are reasonably predictable.  Unwarned emergencies usually consist of onsite emergencies such as a spill, fire/explosion, or a chemical release.  As a responsible company, Arden coordinates emergency response activities with the local emergency management organizations.  This ensures prompt response and mitigation actions during incidents.

Facility description and regulated substances handled

Arden International is a domestic producer of processed food products.  The Lakeville, Minnesota plant site covers approximately 88,400 square feet and the facility grounds total 18.28 acres within the Lakeville City limits.  It is located at 21150 Hamburg Avenue in Lakeville, Minnesota, Dakota County.

There are approximately 100 employees at the plant site at any one time. 

Only one chemical covered by 40 CFR Part 68 is inventoried at the Lakeville site.  This substance is present in quantities greater than the threshold quantity identified by the RMP regulation and therefore is included in our risk management program.

Ammonia (anhydrous) - Ammonia is used as a refrigerant at the plant.  It is received into the plant by truck, however deliveries of ammonia are infrequent.  One of the primary refrigeration vessels is the Low Pressure Receiver vessel. This vessel has a maximum inventory of 10,582 pounds that is controlled through administrative procedures.  The refrigeration system at the facility has a total capacity of approxima

tely 24,800 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.

Accidental release program & chemical-specific prevention steps

Arden contracted with an outside consulting firm to assist in the refinement of the prevention program tailored exclusively to ammonia refrigeration operations.  This prevention program was designed around mechanical integrity and training aspects.  The primary objective of the prevention program is to ensure complete containment of ammonia through safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system.

Arden completed a revalidation of its process hazard analysis (PHA) of the ammonia refrigeration system in March 2009.  The recommendations generated during this review were prioritized using a standardized Risk Rank Matrix method and resolution will be in a timely fashion.

Five year accident history

Arden has a very comprehensive Incident Reporting and Investigation procedural process.  This process is defined and explained in the prevention program procedures.  Basically, an incident occurs when a deviation from expected performance is experienced.

Individuals knowledgeable in refrigeration operation or the equipment being investigated lead formal incident investigations.  Root cause and corrective actions are determined and formal reports are prepared.  Progress regarding corrective action on all investigated incidents is tracked through final resolution.

Arden has not had an accidental release of ammonia within the past five years that resulted in an onsite injury or adversely affected the community.


Emergency response Program

Arden?s emergency evacuation plan has been designed to address likely incidents arising from our ammonia refrigeration system.  The emergency plan is a vital part of Arden?s overall prevention program.  Arden continues to plan for the unplanned ammonia release while striving to adhere to the latest mechanical integrity and inherently safer technologies.


Planned improvements to reduce risk

In accordance with its risk mana

gement program, Arden conducts continuous self-examination evaluations designed to identify and assess process/operational risk employees and the community.  One of the primary aspects of the risk management program is the empowerment of each employee with the responsibility for continuous safe operations.  

The ammonia refrigeration employs a programmable logic controller as a means to control ammonia emissions and inadvertent ammonia releases to the atmosphere.  An audio, visual, olfactory leak detection and repair program that requires multiple checks per day will control refrigeration system emissions.  In addition, ammonia detectors are strategically located throughout the machine rooms to quickly detect any releases.
